all_data.speaker: Chris Jones
all_data.transcript: So I want to throw out something about BECCS. I don't know how many folks have talked about thought about that technology. I find it fascinating from an engineering perspective because one of the interesting things about biomass as an energy source or a feedstock for anything is that it's very distributed. So if you manage start to think about BECCS as a power source as well as a way to produce negative emissions, you're now talking about very distributed CO2 or carbon storage. And so that leads me to thinking about a future landscape that has either a massive amount of CO2 pipelines if we're going to sequester CO2 geologically or a massive reliance on biochar and the associated costs with shipping solids around for sequestration. And so I'm just I'm unsure which of those two is is lower hanging fruit and more likely to be attainable in the in the short term because both from a systems engineering and logistics perspective seem complex to me. But if you look at climate models, there's always a massive amount of BECCS that's suggested as a solution for our negative emissions challenge. And in principle the two parts are there, bioenergy and carbon capture and sequestration, but putting them all together into a system seems really challenging to me.
all_data.other: This is a long, well-articulated monologue that successfully shifts the topic and re-engages the group.

Idea Management.score_justification: The utterance introduces a new, complex idea (BECCS) and elaborates on its distributed nature, challenges, and potential solutions with significant detail and reasoning, moving the team forward.

Knowledge Sharing.score_justification: Chris provides accurate and detailed information about BECCS, including its engineering perspective, logistical challenges, and relevance in climate models, which is highly useful for the team.

Evaluation Practices.score_justification: Chris offers a constructive critique of the two BECCS approaches, providing clear reasoning based on systems engineering and logistics, which helps the team understand the challenges.
